comments.commentBody: What will Adelson and the Kochs do with a candidate whom they cannot buy?
Why in God's name would Cruz be more acceptable than Trump?

A pox on both their houses, I say.

Jim Webb has a resume that no other candidate out their can even approach and is less beholden than any of the rest of the bunch to the corporatocracy and AIPAC.

He understands the system well enough to appreciate how well and truly broken it is - aside from Rand Paul, he is the only one who has been trying to address the problem of runaway executive power and the marginalization of the legislative branch.

Here's hoping he will come through with a strong independent run.

If Webb won enough states to control the balance of votes in the Electoral College (as Wallace intended to do in 1968) the Democrats would be desperate to deal with him to avoid it going to the House of Representatives where they would be certain to lose (each state gets one vote if that happens - the Democrats have a majority in the congressional delegations of only 14 states).

Republicans, naturally, would be desperate to keep him from throwing in with the Dems and losing in the Electoral College.

And if it brought the whole major party duopoly edifice crashing down, 99% of us would be better off.

Time to order up popcorn and brace for interesting times...

When Cohn and others use the term "Republican establishment," they are referring to the group of "old money" and "big business" members of the party who have been in control of the GOP for decades. For years, that group has used social issues (e.g., abortion, prayer in the schools) and veiled racial references to gain the votes of whites in the South and of blue collar whites who realize that their economic situation isn't getting any better but don't know why, and has used the political power generated by those votes to enact laws that benefit big business and the rich at the expense of everyone else.

Finally, many of those voters are starting to realize that they have been duped, and they are angry about it. That's why the GOP establishment no longer is able to control them, and the results of their anger are unlikely to be beneficial for either the GOP or the nation.

Why all the hand-wringing about the "Republican Establishment" not getting what they want?

It may be considered "quaint", but some of us believe that if the people are finally able to reject all the "puppets", and select a non-puppet with broad popular support, that is a *good* thing.

Obama won in 2008 by a huge margin, because he best impersonated an economic populist. Funny, economic populism is just fine if it serves to elect someone who ends up appointing the same Rubin clan to protect the interests of the wealthy, and rig the economy for continued steady downward real wages for the masses. But if a non-puppet uses economic populism - and actually might fight for the economic well being of the masses, that is a "scary and terrible thing".

This economic populist sentiment has been brewing for a long time - the public was fed up enough to vote overwhelmingly for a fake populist who is black, and has a Muslim sounding name - so don't try to paint economic populism as equivalent to racism.

But, go ahead and try to keep eliminating all the candidate choices who actually want to help the working and middle classes reverse this decades long downward economic trend - such as Bernie or Trump.

But then don't be surprised if, down the road, the people get so fed up, that they will elect someone worse than Trump, rather than vote for yet another puppet like Hillary, Rubio, or the like.

replies.commentBody:
Reagan,
Wow. Too much truth for one itty bitty NYT comment.
I have been amusing myself using incite instead of insight. I have had too much of insight and not enough incite.

comments.commentBody:
Yeah, let's worry about the GOP. They're in *such* *big* trouble.

Do liberals/progressives/Democrats -- I am one -- ever find time to understand that the GOP is running this nation and have for 7+ years exposed Democrats as believe-in-nothing, fight-for-nothing be worthless, impotent, hormoneless political clowns.

When will you learn? Would a Republican President, House, Senate, 7-2 Supreme Court, Constitutional-Amendment-passing control of the states wake you chin-stroking, brainless frogs in boiling water up?

But yeah, let's ponder the dire straits of the Republican Establishment, who, by the way, share the same goals as the clowns who appear to be in charge.

Sorry, Cohn. Too easy, no points. Write something that might suggest you have some insight.

replies.commentBody:
With Trump and Carson commanding so much attention, how can you say the dodos are dead?

They have arisen in human form and are coming to eat our brains!

comments.commentBody: I would like to see a specimen of this elusive "moderate" Republican.  The last one I can remember was John Huntsman and we know how that turned out.  Let's see things as they are:  the moderate Republican is as dead as the dodo.

replies.commentBody:
Can you imagine a party so pathetic and impotent as to lose to GOP clowns behaving obnoxiously and intentionally harming the nation for 7 going on 30+ years. It's not possible, is it? No party could manage to stink it up so bad, no party could fail to give their voters something to vote for and lose to this putrid group of wacko conservatives, could it?

I can think of one party that continues to lose to them. Can you?

comments.commentBody:
Others have said it but I must pile on. How can you say Cruz is acceptable in any way for this country? Trump, obnoxious as he is, is not as dangerous as Cruz.
GOP seems to have a candidate for every single-issue voter, so angry at being lied to by the GOP and yet still believe GOP's trope of Obama's a Kenyan undercover agent. They should get their 'conservative' hate radio in check.
Democrats--we're not perfect but better turn out big time. The GOP has gone off the rails completely.

replies.commentBody:
Exactly! Why bother with having someone S -- who must take donations from plutocrat P in order to get elected -- making decisions that may or may not be what P wants -- when you could just have plutocrat P himself making the decisions?

Good thinking, buddy.

comments.commentBody:
The establishment is corrupt. NH gets that. Why settle for Hillary when you can directly elect the people who fund her for favors in return? In this case Trump.

He said it plainly before and it resonates with NH voters-- "I have paid almost everyone here on the [republican stage] and Hilllary Clinton. I am a business man, I donate so that when I call they pick up the phone." NH knows the only kind of 3 am phone calls Hillary cares to pick up-- those from her wealthy owners.

replies.commentBody:
Trump has long praised Democratic administrations as having better economic records. He is pro SS, and would likely favor massive stimulus, and balanced trade. He is against the minimum wage, but if the stimulus is big enough, that could be a moot point. And he is nothing if not flexible and willing to change course if he is wrong. He will never admit he is wrong, but so long as he changes course (learns and reacts pragmatically to the success or failure of policies - unlike the Austerity and trickle down one-trick-pony, tax cutting ideologues considered "mainstream") how important is that?

Agree completely that Trump has tacked far to the right in order to win the *Republican* nomination, and will obviously be tacking to the left for the general election. He will run *far* to the populist left of Hillary, paint her as a Wall Street puppet (piece of cake), and crush her in the general election. I would prefer Bernie, but if Trump is the only candidate willing and able to pry Goldman Sach's and Citibank's fingers off the steering wheel of the US and world economy, I will vote Trump over Hillary - for sure.

comments.commentBody: And imagine if Trump somehow wins the Republican nomination (not impossible) and then jettisons the party to promise a fusion government including some Democrats and Democratic policies (universal health care?)  in his administration? That could be a tough nut for Hillary to crack in November.

replies.commentBody: Hillary will trump the Donald or anybody in the debates. You saw how she defanged the rabid GOP inquisitors in the Benghazi "trial" fiasco that ran 12 hours. Imagine Trump facing a composed, knowledgeable iron lady in a series of debates.
At last a reason to regret the prohibition of internet gambling.

comments.commentBody:
Leave it to the know-nothings at the NYTimes to spin this amazing Trump run negatively: "dangerous", "problem", "disarray", etc.
Trump is appealing to Americans across the country and it drives the liberals crazy with rage and jealousy.
Too bad. In your heart you know Trump will be our next president - - and the New York Times can go stew.

replies.commentBody:
What is Trump's record, so far, in creating and protecting middle-class jobs?

Trump is out for Trump first and only!
I share your sentiment but I find that you are projecting it onto a man who is neither dignified nor wise enough to manage the country.

comments.commentBody:
If Trump wins maybe we start acting in a way that helps create middle class jobs and pass laws that help small businesses grow and create more jobs.

Everyone would follow Trump if that happens. You may not like the guy however I believe he will help our country create middle class jobs and the lack of these jobs is what causing the income inequality.
For all those who believe "Trump can create jobs"--how many times has Trump led companies into bankruptcy?
Just what is a moderate establishment Republican nowadays? It's still supply-side trickle-down voodoo economics that put us in the mess we are in.

Trump Exit Strategy Now Underway? We have ample evidence now that Donald Trump is seeking a way out of the presidential race. He said in October that there is "only one way" he would leave the race -- if his poll numbers drop. Then he said he'd drop out if he saw he was going to lose (without specifying the primary vs. general election).

In furtherance of this exit strategy, Trump has been doing almost everything possible to alienate huge groups of voters -- Iowans, Latinos, women, etc. He's also alienated supporters of the other GOP presidential candidates by attacking their heroes viciously and repeatedly.

Trump is no dummy -- he knows he wouldn't do well as a President. The very idea of slowly shepherding legislation through Congress is abhorrent to him. He know the presidency is filled with compromise, personal attacks, unexpected crises and inevitable failures. And he doesn't want it. Not one bit. Just look at his refusal to issue any serious position papers on the most important (and frequently complex) issues of the day.

In the end, Trump the carnival barker just wanted a few months in the limelight and a chance to blast other people on a national stage -- for free!

Exit strategy? Yep. It's gaining speed with each passing day...

Sometime early next year Republican moneyed interests will put forward a candidate of their choosing for the GOP nomination for President.
They will strongly support this person with excessive funding and a no holds barred and very nasty campaign against the Democratic front runner.

The Republican electorate will fall into line because of exhaustion, disgust, uncertainty, fear of a Democratic juggernaut along with their usual sheep like, unthinking, follow the Pied Piper behavior.
The Republican electorate for the most part is uninformed and/or easily misinformed.
They are easily led around by their very long noses.
They cling desperately to their single-issue voting habits, as well as their traditional conservative view of the world - no matter how out-of-date and redefined it happens to be.

Most of them do not realize that the Republican party of days gone by no longer exists. The current Party has left them and they are unaware of this fact.

How is all this possible? Because we are no longer a democracy and "government of, by, and for the people" is now nothing more than wishful thinking.
The concepts of social and economic justice and the "Common Good" have been abandoned. Greed runs rampant - evidenced by the great inequality in wealth and income that now dominates and is promoted by the infamous 1%.
The rest of us must rise to the occasion and cut them off at the election pass.
Politics is not beanbag. And that's the truth.
Carson has begun to sound like Mr. Magoo and Trump is like some hedgehog on acid. Not much to go on for the GOP.

replies.commentBody:
I think ISIS would exist without the Iraq invasion.

Assad is more than enough reason for ISIS!

comments.commentBody:
The "Republican Party establishment" means those Republican candidates acceptable to the NYT.

The analysis really needed here is why the "establishment" field is so weak and fragmented in the first place. This is implied, but unexamined, in the premise that a single "establishment" candidate would lead the race, rendering Trump a non-problem. It begs the question.

I think the explanation is that the actual "establishment" outside the two so-called "parties" prefers the Eisenhower Republican Hillary Clinton. Clinton has already begun attacking Sanders from the right - that is, from her true position - on health care and foreign policy, in the latter case echoing much of the same imperial interventionist rhetoric from the Republicans that is the #1 source of problems like ISIS, etc., in the first place.

Does anybody think ISIS would exist if the USA had not invaded and occupied Iraq in 2003?

replies.commentBody: You think Donald Trump sounds like a world class leader?  He is arrogant, rude, and dismissive of people who disagree with him.  He calls people names and makes acts like a bully.  He assumes that he can't other countries to do things by insisting on it.  International affairs doesn't work like that; Mexico is not going to build a wall because he tells them to.   He would need to learn to work with people, not merely insult them.
Wow!  I didn't know that making fun of a person's hairstyle or weight made you a world class leader.   We live in interesting times.

comments.commentBody: I don't care how Trump appears to others, to me he is the only candidate in either party who know how to create Jobs, make better deals and act like a world class leader. The world knows him and he does not need any introduction. He has smarts to surround himself with knowledgeable staff to govern this country and Make America Great Again. Ben Carson has imploded, Nobody will ever vote for a Bush, even if he comes in a different cloak. (He is just wasting the money of his backers because the old man Bush is barely hanging on to see a Bush in the White House. Somebody tell him, that will NOT happen. Sanders is full of hot air which he pumps every time with his arm gestures. HE IS SPENT. Hillary will fail facing Trump, because I know!!

The ONLY way for the Republican Party to survive and rebuild is to allow the biggest freak the GOP voters want to be the nominee and for them to go down with a smaller percentage than Barry Goldwater.

When Donald Trump told these people they were the Silent Majority (they are really rather loud) redux, they had already thought that for years...because Fox News and Rush, et al has told them so.

The ONLY way to get through to them is to not be able to blame the party's loss on the candidate being too moderate. The only way to do that is to nominate the most 'conservative' aka reactionary theocrat they can and go down with them.

Oh, if the GOP doesn't want to ever go through this again, they will need to work with Democrats to develop a Fairness Doctrine for the 21st century.

replies.commentBody:
You are correct about the GOP and the religious right, but the GOP has been cheating the religious right for a long time and that has finally been noticed.

The religious right first gained their power over the GOP by staying home and leaving the GOP to be defeated.

They may just do that again because the GOP has become too obvious in their deceit while the Democrats have become a better home for the religious right. At least Democrats are honest about what they support.

comments.commentBody:
The only way Republicans have been able to be elected over the past 25 years, is to appeal to the religious right and the religious in general -- and they did/do so by implying that Democrats are liberal, and that liberals are immoral. This message has been repeatedly drummed in and has worked. That is how they are elected. This group of religious Americans are not in any way concerened about the self-serving greed that the party stands for.

So, yes, the Republicans are now controlled by a conservative element that they must acquiesce to in order to win.

For the sake of the future of this country, I hope they sink this time.

replies.commentBody: Toss in blabbering about Planned Parenthood from middle aged males to complete the rot.

comments.commentBody: What's happening to the GOP is basically very simple.  After 20 years, Fox News brain rot is finally reaching the acute stage.  You're dealing with voters who have mentally relocated to a far-right Candyland, and been there so long they forgot where they came from.  They're conditioned to get angry whenever anybody says "Mexican" or "Muslim" -- just like Pavlov's dog would slobber when he heard a bell.  Vote for Trump?  They'll vote for anybody who rings the bigot bell long, loud and proud.  That explains the whole outline of the GOP race thus far.

In 1996, Patrick J. Buchanan, the darling of the conservative wing of the party, won the New Hampshire primary, scaring the establishment GOP into action. Bob Dole, their guy, won the nomination. Let's see if Jeb Bush can win or even finish a close second or third before we right the establishment off. There is a lot of power and money there, more than even Trump has or Cruz/Rubio can raise.

I like it that the Republican establishment could never accept Trump.  That means come November, 2016, if Trump wins, they'll be out of power.  What we are seeing with Trump, or may be seeing, is not only a coup within the Republican party but a fundamental realignment in American politics.

replies.commentBody:
Could YOU tell me what the platform of Trump and Cruse is?

That's even more opaque.

comments.commentBody: Could you tell us what the platform of the Republican "Establishment" is so I could know whether to be happy or sad that they are not going to get one of their own to the nomination?
